title: Teachings on Righteousness
shortSummary: Matthew 6 presents Jesus' teaching on sincere righteousness, emphasizing genuine devotion in giving, praying, and fasting. It warns against hypocrisy, encourages trust in God’s provision, and prioritizes seeking God's kingdom above earthly concerns.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Jesus' Sermon on the Mount teachings

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Messiah and Teacher delivering instructions on righteous living and true devotion to God.

keyCharacters.name: Hypocrites
keyCharacters.description: Religious people who perform acts of righteousness to be seen and praised by others rather than God.

definitions.definition: Charitable giving to the poor or needy, an act of righteousness emphasized in Jewish and Christian practice.
Those who pretend to be righteous outwardly but lack true devotion and sincerity before God.
A private room or secluded place where one prays in secret, symbolizing intimate communion with God.
A term for wealth or material riches, often personified as a false master competing with God for one’s loyalty.

outline.heading: Warning Against Hypocrisy in Giving
outline.description: Jesus instructs believers to give alms in secret rather than for public praise, promising that God will reward those who give sincerely.

outline.heading: Proper Attitude in Prayer
outline.description: Jesus teaches private, sincere prayer over public display, provides the model prayer (The Lord’s Prayer), and stresses forgiveness as essential for receiving God’s forgiveness.

outline.heading: Fasting with the Right Heart
outline.description: Believers are urged to fast discreetly, avoiding outward signs of suffering to seek God’s reward rather than human approval.

outline.heading: Treasure and the Heart’s Focus
outline.description: Jesus contrasts earthly treasures with heavenly ones, teaching that where one’s treasure is, the heart will follow, and warns against serving both God and wealth.

outline.heading: Trusting God’s Provision
outline.description: Jesus encourages believers not to worry about material needs but to trust God’s care, seeking first His kingdom and righteousness.

application: Practice giving, praying, and fasting with sincerity and humility, seeking God's approval rather than human praise.
Use the Lord’s Prayer as a model to deepen your personal prayer life, emphasizing forgiveness and dependence on God.
Focus your heart on eternal treasures by prioritizing God’s kingdom over material wealth.
Trust God daily for your needs and avoid anxiety about the future by relying on His faithful provision.

keyVerses.text: But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of private, sincere prayer and God's promise to reward genuine devotion.

keyVerses.text: Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal:
keyVerses.significance: These verses teach believers to value eternal, heavenly treasures over temporary earthly possessions.

keyVerses.text: But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes the chapter’s call to prioritize God’s kingdom and righteousness above all else, trusting Him for provision.
